definition: Policies focused on reducing greenhouse gas emissions from the transportation sector (e.g., CO₂ standards, carbon taxes, emissions reporting)
Policies supporting electric vehicles (EVs), charging networks, electric public transit, and electrification of freight fleets.
Policies promoting fuels that emit less carbon than gasoline or diesel—biofuel mandates, hydrogen standards, renewable diesel, e-fuels.
Policies reducing the need to travel or shifting demand to more efficient modes (e.g., congestion pricing, telecommuting, carpool incentives).
Urban planning policies that reduce sprawl by designing compact, walkable cities and aligning transportation with development (e.g., Transit-Oriented Development).
Policies expanding and improving public transit, cycling, walking infrastructure, micromobility (e-bikes, scooters), and multimodal networks.
Investment and regulation for roads, bridges, rail, transit lines, ports, bike networks, and general transportation facilities (maintenance + new projects).
Policies preparing transport systems for climate impacts like flooding, heat, storms, sea-level rise (e.g., resilient roads, elevated rail lines).
Ensuring fair access to transportation for low-income, rural, marginalized communities; affordable mobility and environmental justice goals.
Rules and infrastructure improving safety for all users—speed limits, Vision Zero programs, vehicle crash standards, pedestrian safety design.
Policies focused on freight logistics, ports, trucking, rail cargo efficiency, reducing pollution from shipping and heavy-duty transport.
How transportation is paid for—fuel taxes, tolls, federal grants, private partnerships, road pricing, budget allocation.
Legal and institutional frameworks: government agencies, regulatory approvals, interdepartmental coordination, compliance enforcement.
Policies for emerging mobility tech—autonomous vehicles, ride-hailing, ITS systems, smart traffic control, connected vehicles, MaaS platforms.
Policies targeting air pollution (PM2.5, NOx, ozone) and health impacts from transportation: noise, asthma, emissions near highways.
Programs that change user behavior through education, incentives, and awareness campaigns (car-free days, cycling incentives, transit marketing).
Rules that regulate fuel efficiency, emission limits, manufacturing standards, clean vehicle technologies, fleet standards.
Policies ensuring transportation works for people with disabilities—ADA compliance, low-floor buses, accessible stations, adaptive signals.
